Name: Headless Statue of King Merenptah
Description: This is a headless statue of King Merenptah of the Nineteenth Dynasty. The king stands in the classical attitude with his left leg forward; his hands are holding cylindrical objects. He has a false beard and wears the Usekh broad collar upon his chest. Below the collar, there are the fasteners of a piece of jewelry that cover the external part, surmounted by the sun disk. His two cartouches are carved on the front of his right leg, as well as his epithets as Lord of the Two Lands. The king is dressed in a pleated kilt with a large belt decorated with his cartouche. According to the inscribed text, the statue dates to the second year of Merenptah's reign.
